data.text: A large piece of woven material used as a covering for warmth, especially on a bed.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A layer that covers or encloses.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Applying to or covering all conditions or instances.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Applying to or covering all members of a class.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To cover with or as if with a blanket.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To cover so as to inhibit, suppress, or extinguish.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: blanketed the grease fire with sand.

data.text: To apply to generally and uniformly without exception.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: high telephone service charges that blanketed our region.

data.text: To cover with a blanket or as with a blanket: as, to <internalXref urlencoded="blanket">blanket</internalXref> a horse.
To toss in a blanket by way of punishment or practical joke.
To take the wind out of the sails of, as the sails of one vessel when it is passing close to windward of another.
